title: Thomas Adair Butler
text:
Thomas Adair Butler <a href="Victoria%20Cross">VC</a> (12 February 1836 – 17 May 1901) was an <a href="England">English</a> recipient of the <a href="Victoria%20Cross">Victoria Cross</a>, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> and <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> forces.
Early life.
Born at <a href="Soberton">Soberton</a>, <a href="Hampshire">Hampshire</a>. He was the son of the Rev. Stephen Butler, of Bury Lodge, <a href="Hambledon%2C%20Hampshire">Hambledon, Hampshire</a>, by his first wife Mary Ann Thistlethwayte, daughter of Thomas Thistlethwayte (1779–1850), of <a href="Southwick%20Park">Southwick Park</a>; <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> of Hampshire, hereditary Constable of <a href="Porchester%20Castle">Porchester Castle</a> and warden of the Forest of Bere. He was a nephew of Rear-Admiral Sir <a href="Francis%20Augustus%20Collier">Francis Augustus Collier</a>.
He was educated privately and gazetted as <a href="Ensign%20%28rank%29">Ensign</a> to the <a href="Royal%20Munster%20Fusiliers">1st Bengal European Fusiliers</a>, 9 June 1854; Lieutenant, 23 November 1856, and was afterwards Instructor of Musketry. He served in the <a href="Indian%20Mutiny">Indian Mutiny</a> from 10 June 1857, was in all the engagements under the walls of <a href="Delhi">Delhi</a>, was galloper to <a href="John%20Nicholson%20%28East%20India%20Company%20officer%29">General Nicholson</a> at the action of Nugafshot, and took part in the Storming of Delhi. He also took part in the actions of Gungehri, Pu and Minpoorie and was present at the Siege and capture of <a href="Lucknow">Lucknow</a> where he won the Victoria Cross.
Details.
He was 22 years old, and a <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> in the <a href="1st%20European%20Bengal%20Fusiliers">1st European Bengal Fusiliers</a> (later <a href="Royal%20Munster%20Fusiliers">Royal Munster Fusiliers</a>) during the <a href="Indian%20Mutiny">Indian Mutiny</a> when the following deed took place on 9 March 1858 at <a href="Lucknow">Lucknow</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, for which he was awarded the VC:
Further information.
He later served in the <a href="Umbeyla%20Campaign">Umbeyla Campaign</a> and achieved the rank of <a href="major">major</a> in the service of the <a href="101st%20Regiment%20of%20Foot">101st Regiment of Foot</a>.
The medal.
His Victoria Cross is displayed at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst</a>.
